title: Comment from Sarah Weintraub Schommer
comment:
Office of Personnel Management
Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004
RIN 3206-AO80

I am writing because I oppose the OPM's proposed new rule to reclassify 50,000 federal workers. This reclassification would make it easier to fire federal workers for political reasons. This is unfair to them and it is not what our country needs. We need devoted public servants to be supported in doing their jobs, and for those jobs to be stable. This rule would further undermine our functioning government, be an affront to workers, and undermine faith in our government overall.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
this is a terrible idea. The underlying logic of this proposal is that, 1) all federal employees, no matter where they are located or what they do, must first and foremost be loyal to the President. This is, of course, patently ridiculous. 2) It implies that anyone can do any Federal employee's job; there is no requirement for institutional knowledge or specialization, or years of experience. This, too, is patently ridiculous. Federal employees hold positions ranging from lower-level (security guards and janitors, for example) to highly educated and experienced roles (research scientists and administrators). In any of these roles, Federal employees need to first perform the duties of the position to the level expected in their performance documents. As part of that review process, they should not be working against the government, no matter who the President is at the time. However, allegiance to that President above all else, as implied here, is UNAMERICAN and ACONSITUIONAL.

If implemented, it would move us further into authoritarianism with Federal employees whose allegiance, rather than skill, earns them employment. It would weaken services and disrupt our national security. None of this improves Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service; rather, it would destroy the Civil Service.

I utterly oppose this proposed new rule; I call for the OPM to withdraw it and, instead, make some attempt to follow existing legal and procedural guidelines for classifying--and, when necessary but ONLY when necessary, removing--federal employees.

title: Comment from Pamela Elders
comment:
I object to OPM's proposed new rule that would reclassify 50,000 federal workers to "at-will" employees. "At-will" employment will make it easier to fire any employee for political rather than merit-based reasons. Under "at-will" employment, no reason is required for termination. And, there is little recourse for appeal. 

US civil servants are not political appointees and as such are not subject to removal by Presidential authority. The Civil Service was established to create a professional, non-partisan workforce rather than one based on cronyism. Fealty to the President and his agenda should never be a condition of civil service employment and yet, this is exactly what this proposed regulation seeks to establish. The regulation authors say the reclassification will make it easier to fire employees for "intentionally subverting Presidential directives." This is moving our government further in the direction of a dictatorship. This reclassification effort is a huge over-reach by the Executive Branch which will undermine the federal workforce and reduce public trust in government. 

Another reason given for changing civil servants to at-will employees is that the current protections employees enjoy (e.g., a fair workplace) purportedly makes it difficult "to hold employees accountable." If that is the case, improve the evaluation system. 

The drafters of this rule assert that "positions will remain career jobs filled on a non-partisan basis." This is a disingenuous claim. At-will employment undermines career employment. Job security and due process for employees are critical assurances to those who seek a career job in the federal government. These do not rule out a robust training and evaluation program to ensure good job performance. 

In addition, the assertion that one can be fired without due process for "intentionally subverting Presidential directives" undermines the professional, non-partisan character of civil service positions. The message is clear. Obey or be gone. No professional person would choose to work under such conditions. Our government has long upheld model employment regulations. Let's not abandon our commitment to a fair working conditions for a President's political gain.

title: Comment from Peter Sokol-Hessner
comment: Converting scientific positions into political appointees makes no more sense that hiring firefighters, waiters, or plumbers because of their favorite color - it's irrelevant and can have only one possible effect on science: it will hinder progress and waste money (because appointees will spend tax dollars on poorly-conceived, outdated, impossible, or already-addressed scientific directions). The US is a world-leader in science - everyone agrees that we lead the way in nearly all domains. That dominance is due to continued, long term smart investment in science and scientists. Political appointees in this domain would constitute a shockingly wasteful and partisan change. Because science touches all our lives in terms of medicine, business, policy, agriculture, policing, technology, weather, immigration, the economy, and so much more, this will quite literally eventually cost lives. Political appointees do not belong at the NSF.

title: Comment from Miles Ingram
comment: It is critical to evaluate this proposed rule in the larger context of the current Executive Branch efforts to erode the fair and objective administration of government, and turn the federal bureaucracy into a political tool for rewarding allies and punishing enemies of the current President. It is nothing short of a theft of the entire Executive branch from an institution that belongs to the American public to one that belongs to one man alone—Donald Trump. This rule is one part of a larger project to do what our founders most feared—turn the President into a king. To ignore this context and consider only the narrow technicalities of the proposal would either be willful blindness or purposeful manipulation of the rule-making process by those who naively and selfishly believe they will receive some favor from the would-be king. Nearly 250 years of American democracy are on the line.

title: Comment from A H
comment: I oppose schedule F chiefly because science in the United States should be free from political interference. While science can guide policy making, policy goals should never guide science. The current research funding strategy employed by the National Institutes of Health ensures that sound, rational scientific studies are funded via rigorous peer review by those with the requisite expertise to understand the proposed studies and their impacts on human health. If we were to replace these reviewers with those who are biased towards and away from certain studies due to their personal beliefs or policy goals, we would cripple the advancement of our understanding of threats to the health of all Americans. This would not only be a disservice to the American people, but it would destroy the United States' reputation as THE global leader in biomedical discovery and innovation.

title: Comment from Martha Frommelt
comment:
I am submitting a commentary on the Office of Personnel Management, Docket ID: )PM-2025-0004/RIN 3206-AO801.

Keeping our civil service non-partisan is essential for running our government.  Re-classifying federal worker categories undermines this non-partisan approach and will lead to chaos, brain/experience drain, delays in work flows and more every time there is a new president.  Our continuous improvement as a government and country depends on keeping politics out of the work.  The work should be focused on how to best deliver the service, even if that means civil servants have to offer differing options and approaches that are currently in political favor.  In addition, civil servants need to complete their mission without fear of political reprisals.

Do not reclassify federal worker categories.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
I am writing to express strong opposition to the Office of Personnel Management’s (OPM) proposed rule OPM-2025-0004-0001, which seeks to reclassify approximately 50,000 federal employees into a newly designated Schedule Policy/Career (P/C) category. This proposal, a revival of the previously rescinded Schedule F, threatens the foundational principles of a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service and poses significant risks to the integrity, efficiency, and accountability of federal operations.

All Federal Agencies rely on the continuity that apolitical civil servants provide.  They swear an oath to uphold the Constitution, not any one elected official, and it should be that way.  Their job is to carry out policies for the current administration within the bounds of the law.  Current job protections are in place to see that employees are removed for performance causes, not ideological cause.

This proposal, a revival of the previously rescinded Schedule F, threatens the foundational principles of a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service and poses significant risks to the integrity, efficiency, and accountability of federal operations.

All Federal Agencies rely on the continuity that apolitical civil servants provide.  They swear an oath to uphold the Constitution, not any one elected official, and it should be that way.  Their job is to carry out policies for the current administration within the bounds of the law.  Current job protections are in place to see that employees are removed for performance causes, not ideological cause.

title: Comment from Judith Mitchell
comment:
I am a private individual strongly opposing the Office of Personnel Management’s proposed regulation – [Docket ID OPM-2025-0004] RIN 3206-AO80.

The stated reason for the proposed rule is to “allow agencies to quickly remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct, perform poorly, or . . .  intentionally [subvert] Presidential directives.”  (Summary 90 FR 17182)  However, this appears to be a thinly disguised effort to impose a “loyalty to President Trump test” for federal employees and fire those employees who are considered not sufficiently loyal to the President.  

The proposed rule may give “lip service” to the E.O. 14171 “directive” that an employee is “not required to pledge personal loyalty to the President or his policies” (Section 213.3501  90 FR 17201), however, if that employee is classified as “at will” and is fired because, for example, he or she is registered to a political party other than the one currently in office, how does that employee fight that wrongful termination?

The Summary states that “[a]gency supervisors report great difficulty removing employees for poor performance or misconduct.” (Summary 90 FR 17182).  There is no cite supporting that assertion.  And while making the process easier for supervisors to take adverse actions for employee misconduct may be a worthwhile objective, reclassifying employees in order to strip them of employees’ appeal rights is not logical and from what I have read may not be lawful. The December 2016 publication “Addressing Misconduct in the Federal Civil Service: Management Perspectives”  states at page 3: 

“Ultimately, what the survey data indicate is that there is some disagreement among supervisors about how many rights the system should provide to employees, including the desired extent of appeal and grievance rights. But, there is little disagreement on one crucial point – supervisors overwhelmingly want a merit-based system where employees are protected from managers who either make mistakes or act in bad faith. “
https://www.mspb.gov/studies/researchbriefs/Addressing_Misconduct_in_the_Federal_Civil_Service_Management_Perspectives_1363799.pdf   

The proposed rule does not address the problem of underperforming employees.  Quoting from the OPM Rule “Upholding Civil Service Protections and Merit System Principles”  [Docket ID: OPM-2023-0013]  RIN 3206-AO56 :

“[T]he characteristics of an employee's job—including whether the employee works on policy—has nothing to do with an employee's performance. Schedule F sought to streamline terminations based on the type of work that an employee performs, not based on how well the employee performs. It is therefore difficult to understand how Schedule F can be reconciled with its purported aim of addressing poor performance.”  89 FR 24995

In my opinion it is not “difficult to understand” how reclassification addresses poor performance, it makes no rational sense whatsoever.  

I am 74 years old and retired.  I receive Social Security based on my 40 years of work and rely on Medicare for health insurance coverage.  It is very important to me that the Social Security Administration employs reliable, knowledgeable employees and that human beings in the office are accessible by telephone, in person and online.  

I have always paid my taxes and believe that it is a responsibility of everyone who lives in this country to pay his or her fair share of taxes.  I rely on the Internal Revenue Service to promptly review my annual returns and promptly issue whatever refund I may be entitled to.  It is important to me that the I.R.S. be fully staffed with reliable, knowledgeable employees.

As I age, I recognize more and more how important scientific and medical research is for the health of my children and grandchildren.   My family and I will be adversely affected if research is slowed into preventative and curative therapies for respiratory viruses and infections, stroke recovery, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and other diseases and conditions that directly impact my life.  I rely on the Department of Health and Human Resources to be fully staffed with reliable and knowledgeable employees.

I do not trust that the proposed rule will improve the delivery of services by expert and experienced employees.  I believe it will greatly reduce the quality of services (paid for with our taxes) provided by federal agencies.

title: Comment from Alexander Tsai
comment:
Comment on Proposed Rule: "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" (Docket Number: RIN 3206-AO72)

Introduction

I am submitting this comment as an academic physician-scientist with more than a decade of experience conducting NIH-funded research at Massachusetts General Hospital with appointments at Harvard Medical School and Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. As a researcher with extensive experience in the NIH grant system, I am writing to express significant concerns regarding the section of the proposed rule that designates employees with "substantive participation and discretionary authority in agency grantmaking" as potentially occupying "policymaking positions" that could be reclassified under Schedule Policy/Career.

Specific Concerns with the Proposed Rule

The proposed rule identifies grant-making as "an important form of policymaking" and suggests that employees with "substantive discretionary role in how federal funding gets allocated may occupy policymaking positions." This characterization fundamentally misunderstands the scientific grant review process at agencies like NIH and NSF, which rely on scientific merit and peer review rather than political considerations.

The stated purpose of this rule is to allow agencies to "quickly remove employees from critical positions who engage in misconduct, perform poorly, or undermine the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives." When applied to scientific grant-making, this creates a dangerous framework that could politicize what should be an independent, merit-based process.

Evidence-Based Arguments

The primacy of American scientific research in the world depends on insulating technical grant review from political influence:

1. NIH and NSF grant review processes are designed to fund the most scientifically promising research through rigorous peer review. The NIH is "arguably the most important institution shaping the rate and direction of scientific research" with significant implications for human well-being. Even small changes to how funding is allocated could have massive effects on social welfare.

2. International examples demonstrate the severe consequences when politics interferes with scientific funding decisions. Soviet biology, which had achieved peak prominence by the mid-1930s, was essentially ruined by Lysenko's politically-backed campaign against genetics (Ptushenko, Genetics, 2021). The damage was so profound that even after Lysenkoism was officially renounced in 1964, it took decades for Russian science to recover from this political interference.

3. Similarly, in countries like China where "personal relationships have affected government decisions, such as the review of scientific grants," scientific integrity issues have damaged progress despite massive investments (Zeng et al. Dev World Bioeth, 2010). Studies indicate that politicization of science funding leads to inefficient allocation of resources, limiting China's ability to achieve global scientific leadership commensurate with its spending (Shu et al. Minerva, 2022; Yu et al. Res Policy, 2022).

4. The existing peer review system, while imperfect, provides important guardrails against bias. These decisions should be made by scientific experts, not political appointees.

Specific Recommendations for Improvement

I propose the following improvements to the rule:

1. Explicitly exclude scientific grant review personnel at NIH, NSF, and similar research agencies from the Schedule Policy/Career designation. Scientific merit review is a technical function, not a political one.

2. Provide a clear, narrow definition of what constitutes "substantive discretionary authority" in grant-making that distinguishes between technical evaluation based on scientific merit (which should remain protected) and truly discretionary policy decisions.

3. Add specific safeguards ensuring the independence of scientific peer review committees from political interference, including explicit protections for review panel members.

4. Require transparency in any actions that would redesignate positions related to scientific grant review, including advance notice and comment periods specific to each affected role.

Conclusion

While improving accountability in government service is a worthwhile goal, applying at-will employment status to scientific grant-making personnel poses significant risks to American scientific leadership. The independence of the scientific grant-making process from political influence has been a cornerstone of American research excellence and must be preserved.

title: Comment from Rachel F
comment:
I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.

First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.

Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.

In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Kendra Eshleman
comment: I am writing in opposition to the proposed Office of Personnel Management rule to reclassify tens of thousands of federal workers as Schedule Policy/Career (formerly Schedule F) (Docket ID: OPM-2025-0004). This rule will strip job protections from thousands of federal workers, allowing them to be fired at any time, without cause, including the very administrative judges tasked with enforcing job protections for federal employees. Under the guise of promoting accountability, this rule makes it easier to fire employees not only for poor performance or misconduct, but also for not toeing the ideological party line of the current president. This rule will remove the safeguards that protected the non-partisan nature of the federal workforce, allowing Democrats to serve under Republican presidents and Republicans to keep serving and doing their jobs for the American people under Presidents Obama and Biden. This will undermine Americans' trust that our federal government is working for all of us, regardless of party and ideology.

title: Comment from Virginia Mayne
comment:
I support President Trump’s efforts to bring accountability to the federal bureaucracy. 


For too long, unelected career bureaucrats in the federal government have stifled efficiency by undermining the plans and policies of the Chief Executive.

OPM’s new rule cuts red tape and allows career bureaucrats to be reprimanded for poor job performance or misconduct, such as corruption or partisanship.

In any industry, rogue employees are held accountable to someone. Now, government employees will be held accountable for lack of performance or inaction.


I support President Trump’s work to rein in unaccountable bureaucrats and end the Deep State!

title: Comment from Laura Livingston
comment:
As a federal employee, a Foreign Service Officer in the Department of State for over 25 years, I am appalled at the idea of expanding political appointees in the USG any further than they already exist.  The idea of an entire corps of officers whose loyalty is to the president and political party in power rather than to the oath to defend, protect and uphold the U.S. Constitution is an abomination. After having worked with foreign governments in a variety of countries (Kenya, Nigeria, Venezuela, Panama, Belgium, India) I can assert with great confidence that the countries with the weakest governance (Kenya, Nigeria, Venezuela and Panama) had weak or non-existent civil service employees.  In Panama, after every election, virtually the entire employee roster, from janitors to Ministers, changed, leaving no institutional memory and a new group of employees who often had no idea what to do or how to do it and who spent most of their time undoing what their predecessors had done rather than advance the agenda of the current president.  One of the major saving graces in India, for example, is an extremely strong civil service.  There are highly competitive exams for the Indian Administrative Service, the Indian Police Service and the Indian Foreign Service and members of the IAS, the IPS or the IFS cannot even vote in elections until they retire.  If nothing else, it keeps government administration focused on governing and not on implementing the whims of the current government for fear of losing their jobs.  

Apart from that consideration, it should be crystal clear that the loyalty oaths required of the new "Schedule F" employees would likely be written in the vaguest possible terms, so that virtually anyone who doesn't meet the definition of "loyalty" demanded by someone farther up the ranks from them would be cashiered.  Not only would this lack of protection ensure that the employee's loyalty would be to an individual politician, rather than to defend, protect and uphold the U.S. Constitution, it would also lead to disruption of government functioning, as employees not considered sufficiently "loyal" could be fired at whim, leaving gaping holes for key responsibilities.

We're not a dictatorship . . . yet.  Schedule F is a huge step towards becoming one.
